content.text: Two strings support a load of weight 7.5N, as shown in Fig. 1.2

One string has a tension \(T_{1}\) and is at an angle \(50^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. The other string has a tension \(T_{2}\) and is at an angle \(40^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. The object is in equilibrium. Determine the values of \(T_{1}\) and \(T_{2}\) by using a vector triangle or by resolving forces

content.text: Use Fig. 2.1 to describe the velocity of the car in
The car has a total mass of \(1250\mathrm{kg}.\) Determine the total resistive force acting on the car in stage 2

For safety reasons drivers are asked to travel at lower speeds. For each stage, describe and explain the effect on the distance travelled for the same car and driver travelling at half the initial speed shown in Fig. 2.1
The variation with time \(t\) of velocity \(\nu\) of a car is shown in Fig. 2.1
At time \(t = 0\), the driver sees an obstacle in the road. A short time later, the driver applies the brakes. The car travels in two stages, as shown in Fig. 2.1
1. Use the Young Modulus of the steel to show that the tension in the cable is \(3.1 \times 10^{4} \text{N}\)
2. Calculate the acceleration of the mass as it is lifted from the ground
The motor now lifts the mass through a height of \(15\mathrm{m}\) at a constant speed
1. the tension in the lifting cable,
the gain in potential energy of the mass
The motor of the crane is \(30\%\) efficient. Calculate the input power to the motor required to lift the mass at a constant speed of \(0.55 \text{m s}^{-1}\)
A crane is used to lift heavy objects, as shown in Fig. 3.1

The motor in the crane lifts a total mass of \(1800\mathrm{kg}\) from rest on the ground. The cable supporting the mass is made of steel of Young modulus \(2.4 \times 10^{11}\mathrm{Pa}\). The cross-sectional area of the cable is \(1.3 \times 10^{-4}\mathrm{m}^2\). As the mass leaves the ground, the strain in the cable is 0.0010. Assume the weight of the cable to be negligible
Distinguish between _potential difference_ (p.d.) and _electromotive force_ (e.m.f.) in terms of energy transformations
Calculate the current in the circuit
On Fig. 4.1, draw an arrow to show the direction of the current in the circuit. Label this arrow \(I\)
the terminal p.d. across cell A,
the terminal p.d. across cell B
Two cells A and B are connected in series with a resistor R of resistance \(5.5 \Omega\), as shown in Fig. 4.1
Cell A has e.m.f. 4.4V and internal resistance 2.3. Cell B has e.m.f. 2.1V and internal resistance 1.8
By reference to vibrations of the points on a wave and to its direction of energy transfer, distinguish between transverse waves and longitudinal waves

2. the phase difference between the points labelled A and B

The source of \(\alpha \text{-particles}\) is replaced with a source of \(\beta \text{-particles}\)

The electric field gives rise to an acceleration of the \(\alpha \text{-particles}\) and the \(\beta \text{-particles}\). Determine the ratio

A horizontal beam of \(\alpha \cdot\) -particles from a radioactive source is made to pass between the plates
